DOC.HEAD: Upjohn Will Take $200 Million Fourth-Quarter Charge
DOC.TEXT: Upjohn Co. said Wednesday it would phase out production of industrial chemicals at a North Haven, Conn. plant and take a $200 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings to reflect that and other restructuring steps. Upjohn would scale back production at the plant and planned to sell its industrial chemical product lines and technologies next year, Chairman Theodore Cooper said in a statement. ``The industrial chemical business no longer fits our corporate strategy,'' Cooper said, adding that the North Haven plant had become unprofitable because of a number of factors, including obsolescence, competition and shrinking markets. Most of the 178 jobs at the plant would be phased out by the end of 1992, some through normal attrition and early retirement incentives, the company said. Upjohn said 65 percent of the $200 million charge was attributable to the phaseout of the North Haven plant, while the other 35 percent was due to a previously-announced special retirement plan and other one-time expenses. Industrial chemicals include benzephonone, used in soaps and perfumes, DCNA, used in dyes and as an agricultural fungicide, and dichlorobenzidine, used in making yellow ink and dye pigments, Upjohn spokesman J.P. Lambrechts said.
